I've played this game since closed beta (not on steam) and it's my favourite digital CCG so far. Definitely worth a try for every fan of card games.

Pros:
large variety in terms of deck building (the 6 colours can be freely combined)
the speed, and front and support row systems shake up traditional CCG combat a bit
generous quest system
unlimited deck slots (no Blizzard, more than 9 doesn't confuse us)
has a mechanic to mitigate resource screw/flood
tournament and spectator mode
leaderboards, which show the exact ranking of every player playing ranked
beautiful artwork (at least imo)
Neutral
it takes a few hours to unlock features like crafting or Trials (similar to HS arena)
very little RNG (no BS but also no great highlight reel material)
Cons:
fairly steep learning curve
single player campaigns not yet implemented
options menu is really lacking
some minor bugs here and there-------------------------------------------------------------------
read on for more in depth information:
The combat system functions similar to MtG, but with a few twists. You can directly target your opponents creatures with attacks. However each creature has a speed stat, ranging from 1 to 4, in addition to health and attack. A creature can only ever attack or block a creature with the same or lower speed. A higher speed means more flexibility in combat but comes at the price of lower stats or higher cost.
Creatures can move freely between a front and support line (except when they have previously attacked this turn). While a creature is protected from attacks in the support line, it also can't attack or block itsself, which makes it the perfect place for small creatures with key effects. An exception to this are flying creatures, which can attack as well as block while in the support line.

This game is really generous. You don't have to spend a dime and you can still build a competitive deck in about a week with semi-casual play. As you play you automatically unlock new starter decks and the corresponding faction's quest zones. From unlocking all zones alone you get multiple rares (second highest rarity) and one epic (highest rarity) of every faction. Every 8 hours a variety of quests spawn in one faction zone from which you can choose one. Rewards range from small amounts of gold, a few common or uncommon cards or small packs (4 cards) to 12 pack boxes, rare and epic cards (no duplicates) or premium currency. There's also the academy, which gives you a really good quest once every 3 days.
In the draft mode Trials, which you can enter for a fee, you break even after 3 wins (50% win rate) and at the max of 10 wins you get rewards, which are worth more than 7 times the entry fee (including 5 packs).

For those who want to spend a few bucks there are custom card backs or premium packs, which have higher chances for epics and will not give you cards you already have 4 of (max number which can be included in a deck).

I've been a Magic player on and off since Vth edition. I've also played Jyhad, some Netrunner, Infinity Wars, Hearthstone etc. I was looking for an online TCG that would satisfy me for a long while and I feel this could be it.

Spellweaver is not shallow when it comes to the gameplay itself. It feels a lot like Magic, but slightly different. It adds some depth here and there, while removing some of the aspects that make Magic seem complicated to beginners (such as the stack). The result is satisfying, it doesn't feel like the game or your deck plays itself like in some other TCGs, it never feels like RNG is determining the outcome of the game and although it's still early it feels like a good competitive scene could be built on this game.

The factions are interesting, with clear strengths and weaknesses as well as themes. The software itself is good and I haven't encoutered any major bugs. The occasional server problem still happens, but they usually don't last long and you can simply continue the match if it was interrupted. UI is clear and easy to use, although I'm not a fan of the separation of the Decks and Collection tab. Deckbuilder is not too bad either, but MODO's still my favorite. Animations are present, but short and unintrusive.

If you don't like the excessive simplicity of Hearthstone and aren't happy with the limitations and problems of Magic Duels, give this a try.  It's not a shoddy, poorly thought out card game like most online TCGs and it's not just a bland clone like HEX.

PS: you can't chat with your opponent, only with people on your friends list. Silly limitation and I find it hard to justify it, but I guess that's the trend now - playing online but without human interaction. Shame.

The game itself is really smooth, animations are nice, the sounds fitting. It has tournaments, trials (think arena in Hearthstone or draft mode in Duel of Champions), single- and multiplayer support (play vs bots or play vs people in ranked or unranked mode).

Rarely do I find a card game that piques my interest. At least not since Magic: The Gathering and Hearthstone...both of which can be considered direct influences for Spellweaver. reviewText:
Want a ccg that's more complex than Hearthstone and Cheaper than Magic Online?  This is it.
Pick Dominion first.

Spellweaver has many features that make it one of the best, if not the best digital ccg out now.  You can fully customize your deck, which is a great improvement over hearthstone where you're limited to only your class cards and neutral cards.  This is kept in check with their equivalent of magic's color system.  In Spellweaver there are two main resources: levels and mana.  Your deck consists of Shrines creatures and spells.  Spells and creatures are virtually the same as Magic or Hearthstone the shrines are what makes this game different.

Unlike hearthstone you don't get mana automatically every turn instead you can play a shrine which can give you a level in its particular discipline or a mana crystal and draw a card.  If you are low on shrines, you can use a once a turn ability to exchange a card from your hand to look for a shrine in the top 5 cards in your deck.  These features help prevent the problems magic has of mana flood or mana screw.

Gold accumulation is acceptable in this game and better than hearthstone I'd say.  You accumulate gold for all games you play as well as a bonus for going up player levels.  In addition to games and bonuses, there are also quests which can reward cards, packs, gold or sometimes crystals (the pay only currency).  The pack accumulation rate is about one for every thirteen ranked games won. (I've found I get about 1000 gold on average for winning a ranked game) and you get half gold if you lose, which is way better than hearthstone at one pack for every 30 wins.

Give it a download and try it.

Pick Dominion to start. (For magic players it has rampant growth, wrath of god, and mind control.

My recommended starter deck order:
1. Dominion
2. Wisdom
3. Corruption
4. Rage
5. Order
6. Nature

reviewText:
This game is similar to MtG, and perhaps the most well-designed game of its kind, but sometimes suffers from its relatively low budget.



In MTG vs hearthstone, there are three major design differences: mana, combat, and instants. Spellweaver gets all of those points right:

1) Just like in MtG, lands are used to produce mana and you can have cards from multiple classes, but there is a lot more deck control in Spellweaver, so you very rarely run out of lands to place.

2) In Hearthstone the attacker would always choose who he attacks, and in Magic the defender would always decide. In Spellweaver, they have a speed stat for each creature, and higher speed creatures can block lower speed creatures; if they are not blocked they can attack whatever they want. It's a nice compromise that also adds some room for card diversity.

3) Instants exist in Spellweaver (and so add more depth to the game), but they don't slow the game down because they can only be played at certain times. So you get most of the depth of instants without having to pass priority after every card.



The game suffers a little from its low budget (the kickstarter only got $10k when the final goal was $15k, and it's made by a 5-man dev team that took 4 years to release it):

1) It's not too pretty. The card art is mediocre, worse than MtG or hearthstone imo. There are very few animations, i.e. if someone plays a card that says they instantly win you will only see the win screen, not how they won. The sounds are also fairly repetitive and lackluster.

2) You can't chat in-game. You can add friends and then chat after, but still.

3) The game has a pretty small playerbase, so they might stop developing it at some point... :/

This game should be the new standard for online F2P TCG's, period.

Spellweaver is a M:tG derivative that does improve upon the already known formula with quite a few innovative ideas. The implementation of an extra color for non-control Black magic,  flying tiers (called speed), WoW TCG heroes/hero powers and a permanent, once a turn scry-5-for-land mechanic, plus making card-draw a universal perk of all colors gives it a definitely fast-paced environment where luck is minimized and skill differences can be noticed even in subtle ways. In a nutshell, it has both a lower skill floor and in some areas a higher skill ceiling than Magic.

It's very young, the developers are active and so generous this game is a Play-to-Win. Note the PLAY. I jumped right in trying to find something that could entertain me for an hour or two every now and then, and haven't been able to put it down at all. It's a testament to the developers' ability to take beloved and famous game mechanics and make them feel new, feel modern again.

More than worth a try. Spellweaver is what Card Games should strive to be, and its business model puts every other F2P model to shame. An excellent CCG that is both comfortingly familiar and creatively new.

reviewText:
I'm a long time Magic the Gathering player, and ever since I discovered Spellweaver a little over four months ago it has become my favorite collectible card game. Spellweaver is a combination between Magic the Gathering, Hearthstone and Hex, but has a feel that is distinctly its own.

Pros:
+ You can attack individual creatures like in Hearthstone, and you can interact with the opponent on their turn with instant spells and effects like in Magic.
+ The speed system. Creatures have a speed stat that varies from 1 to 4, and can attack and intercept only creatures with a speed that is equal to or lower than their own speed. All creatures can intercept other creatures, similarly to how Protectors could intercept other creatures in WoW TCG.
+ The two-row system. There's a front row and a support row. Creatures on the front row can attack but also be attacked, whereas creatures on the support row are safe from attacks but cannot attack. Flying creatures are the only ones that can attack from the support row.
+ The Divine Offering mechanic. With Divine Offering, once per turn, you can put a card from your hand on the bottom of the deck, look at the top five cards of the deck, put a resource card in your hand and the rest on the bottom.
+ The hero system. The game revolves around heroes, each having a unique skill like in Hex. Heroes can also acquire additional skills (up to three) with special resource cards.
+ The quest system, which is more generous than in any online card game I've played (maybe too generous). Quests have rarity just like cards (common, uncommon, rare and epic), with rarer ones giving better rewards, including packs and rare/epic cards.
+ The developers and the community. I like it that the developers are active on the game's forum and constantly engage with the community, and that they take advantage of the digital medium and constantly strive to improve and balance it.

(Actually there's more, but I seem to have reached the word limit.)

Cons:
- The number of cards is rather small at the moment.
- Some server issues. Hopefully they'll be fixed soon.
- The tutorial is not that great.
- You can only chat with people in your friends list.

The game is still in its infancy, but I think its long-term potential is huge. I highly recommend it.

This game combines the best aspects of Magic: The Gathering and Heathstone, plus adds original touches that make it stand out. Good game play with numerous deck strategies avaialable, and this is just with the basic set so far. The game play is pretty smooth and the UI is intuitive and looks great. The cards themselves also feature great artwork.

Most Free-to-play digital CCGs require you to dump some cash into the game or spend a ridiculous amount of time grinding to earn cards. Spellweaver is fairly generous with the availability of cards and in game gold used to buy packs, and the crafting system means you can get a couple of key cards you need for your ideal deck without relying on the randomness of opening packs. Very early on I had enough cards to tweak my starter, and in no time I was able to start constructing my own decks, which is the real meat of a CCG for me. I DID end up spending some money on the game, but that was more to support the game than to be competetive. And for those who want to support the game with out feeling like they're buying an advantage, you can buy cosmetic upgrades like card sleaves. I'm more inclined to spend money on games like this when I don't feel like I need to, and when the game is so good I want it to suceed.

Heroes start with a basic skill. You can add additional skills and choose your aspects as you wish (though your basic skill will require levels in your hero's native aspect). I particularly love the speed stat on creatures, which can make for some tricky decisions on when and how to attack, and the divine offering feature, that allows you to sacrifice a card in hand to get a chance at a shrine(these produce mana, skills, and aspect levels). Energy traits on cards also allow for some interesting mechanics (knowledge makes heavy use of these, though other aspects have it as well). You have multiple game options, from varying difficulty AI matches, friendly matches with human opponents, ranked matches to get on the leaderboard, tournaments, draft trials, and sometimes special PvE events as quests. However casual or serious you take your card gameing, Spellweaver has you covered.

If Hearthstone and Magic: The Gathering would have had a baby, it's name would be Spellweaver.

With collectible card games, 3 questions always arise:
1) It is pay to win?
2) It is balanced?
3) What sets it apart from the other card games?

1) It is pay to win?
No, I believe not. There are daily quests and there is no limit to the amount of gold you can collect (without paying). Also, while leveling, you get a lot of free stuff, like gold, card decks and booster packs. For a small card pack you have to win 20 matches against the AI or 5 matches in ranked. Which is fair.

2) It is balanced?
No, in it's current stage the game is not yet balanced. Certain factions have better cards and more synergy. But this is only really noticeable against high ranking players. As a casual player you'll probably not have many issues. Something I personally had an issue with was bad opening hands. The RNG can be pretty annoying sometimes.

3) What sets it apart from the other card games?
You won't find anything new here. You can test your skills against players using your own deck in a friendly match, ranked match or in tournaments held every few days or you could also just play against the AI. Alternatively, you can play trials in which you construct a deck on the fly (draft) and try to win 10 games. Finally, you can do the daily quests and level up your character for extra rewards.


Overall it's a pretty interesting game.

reviewText:
Hearthstone and Magic the Gathering had a baby.. A really awesome baby.

The mechanics are similar to both titles and the card art is gorgeous. The free to play model is fair I find and I'll go into detail on that shortly.

As you play matches you earn gold (Free Earnable Currency) and fame (XP) You can play against AI or against other people and have the option of playing Friendly matches or Ranked games that give you a rating. All cards can be earned through just playing the game and it doesnt feel like your being drip fed a miniscule amount of currency to reach that goal of obtaining more cards and decks.

The deck Building is similar to Magic the Gathering in that you have multiple colours to choose from each with their own gimmicks and playstyles, You can mix them up how you see fit and create a customised deck suited to your playstyle.

Upon first entering the game you are given a choice of 1 of the 6 starter decks available (Which are still somewhat competitive against real people even without adding in cards earned through quests or buying with real money I might add)

Upon reaching level 5 (Roughly a couple hours of gameplay for me) You are given another starter deck and this is were the fun begins.. You can mix your two starter decks together to create a duo element deck as I touched on earlier.

For instance my Order deck (White token and flying focused for those that play MTG) and my newly acquired Nature deck (Elven Aggro which consists of low cost fast creatures and instant speed spells) were mixed together to create a deck that has more options instead of sticking to a set one trick pony strategy and allowing for more variation in what you can do in your player matches.

As you level up you will acquire Rewards for doing so, such as Gold and Packs you could otherwise purchase on the store.

Normal Packs contain 10 random cards and there are also good and evil Booster packs if your looking to get something from those specific factions. Good = Order,Nature and Wisdom/  Evil = Rage, Corruption and Dominion.

There is also a draft format with tournaments being held for prizes and these are unlocked later as you level.

Ranked matches are unlocked at level 3 giving you time to be eased into the game and learn its mechanics.

All in all I really recommend this game, It's free, Fun and you don't have to spend a penny to have a good time although if you want to support the devs I recommend purchasing a double box for either good or evil depending on the factions you want to play with.

This is easily my favourite card game as of now.. Yugioh, Pokemon, Hearthstone and Shadow Era (A f2p Card game similar to this) Havn't given me as much fun as this and I loved playing those games over the years.

Do yourself a favour, Download this 500mb Gem of a game and try it out for yourself, If your a fan of card games you wont be disappointed!

reviewText:
Spellweaver is, in my opinion, the best CCG out right now. I haven't had so much fun creating decks and challening players since the early years of Magic The Gathering. I currently have 8 pages worth of decks based around different ideas and synergies and it is only going to increase with the expansions!

The Artwork is amazing and really pulls you in. The mechanics are innovative yet familiar, drawing the best features from games like Hearthstone and MTG yet improving upon them and making them distinct and original.

There are top players from MMDoC and M:TG who play this game and it is great getting to see them on the leaderboards.

The quest and rewards system is VERY generous for a FTP, if you are an average player you can expect to build some very competitive decks within a few days of simple questing. If you are very skilled you can play Trials and probably get a full set in 3 months. Compare that to Hearthstone where it could take you over a year! While an amazing FTP game, I encourage everyone to take advantage of the 40% bonus crystals for the Steam release.

But perhaps the best part of this game is the Dev team; a small group of independant developers that really listen to the community and seem to constantly be working on and improving elements of the game based on player feedback. Their creativity is novel and exciting; just when you think a card is going to be fixed or nerfed in a predictable way, they surprise you with their innovative thinking.

Believe me, after playing Spellweaver with it's Divine Offering mechanic, skill shrine abilities, hero powers and creature Speed mechanic, it is very difficult to go back to playing other CCGs. They have done the seeming impossible by minimizing RNG while maximizing deck variance. Definitely recommend playing this game if you are even slightly interested in CCGs (and even if you are not!)

Spellweaver is a free trading card battle game complete with a good starter deck to get you going. Isn't that already enough to satisfy your soul?

Spellweaver is a card game that involves a lot of strategy, building a well balanced deck & a little bit of luck when it's your turn to draw cards. The game does have its complexities but makes up for it with lots of rewards including a lot of gold coins to help you improve your deck quickly. It also has a nice long learning curve but once you get the hang of it you're ready to spill some opponent blood.

There is a small cost though. If you want to compete with some of the best online players you'll have to invest in card packs that will give you a chance to unpack 'Rare' or even 'Epic' cards that, when mixed into a strong  multi classed deck, may help you stay on top of the Champion's table amongst some the best players in the world .

Overall, I think this strategic card game can be very entertaining & a blast to play with friends & strangers alike. I give it my purple seal of approval.

It depends a little less in resources rng" than MTG with a mechanic that allows you to discard a card from your hand for the chance of looking at the top 5 cards of your deck for a Shrine. This adds a forgiving mechanic in case the player is having bad luck and not drawing any Shrines

reviewText: Spellweaver is a free to play card game that introduces some, as far as I know, new concepts into the card game genre. The game starts with two tutorials, followed by picking a starter deck. The combat is where some interesting features come in. Each card has a required mana cost and a required level cost. Level and mana are increased during the match by using a domain card. The domain card only allows the player to either increase level or increase mana and draw one card. During combat, the player is able to block an attack from an enemy unit by dragging in another unit that the player has down to take the blow. At first I didn't like this game. I thought it was too slow to gain gold, and it would be yet another Pay2Win game.

But I gave it a chance, and I've come to realize a major difference between this TCG and others - I actually enjoy the gameplay. It's not just another TCG that is about collecting cards and building a deck. You need strategy and tactics in game, and your deck needs to have multiple ways to play to be successful. You don't just sit there collecting cards and hoping you draw your iWin cards in game.

If you like card games with a lot of strategy and depth, I would definitely recommend it.

As for my first concern, that gold gain was slow, it does get better. Each starter deck you get (every 5 levels) unlocks a new quest zone which gives regular quests for extra rewards. And as you level, you also unlock more rewarding ways to play. Playing against humans does give much better rewards than playing against AI, however I find the game play vs humans is not bad... Trials game mode ensures everyone has the same chance at drafting a good deck and doing well, and so far in regular PvP I have not encountered any overpowering decks. Strategy, Tactics, and I suppose a little luck is what wins games, not lots of legendary cards.

reviewText:
This is just a first impressions review and while I do not like the game (it is purely subjective) I do recommend that you give it a go. I am not a Hearthstone fan by any

stretch of the imagination so that might have affected my opinion. If you like MTG+Hearthstone then please do give it a try.

1) Mostly good tutorial but it does not explain order levels very well. Perhaps it was just me but it was not clear when I should be getting 'levels' over mana and cards

which can be detrimental to new players if you start out the round wrong.

2) You get to pick a free premade deck and you can get more later on by playing, but you aren't given a chance to try them all out before picking so you can end up with

something you are not familiar with and unable to use effectively. An option to try out all the available starter decks before picking would be great as well as a basic

tutorial per premade deck type.

3) The art is too small. Sadly this might be my biggest peeve with the game. The cards are tiny and all I see are rectangles flying up and bumping into each other. I get it

that they are going for Magic the Gathering style art but this is a computer game and the cards are too small for me to appreciate having them on the table. Cartoony

artstyles with larger images would have been more ideal for me, but that's just my silly opinion.

Good things about it:

1) You can fight the AI instead of just players. Big plus for me. Rewards are smaller but some people don't mind that.

2) You get enough gold to nearly buy another deck when you start and you get free decks as you level up.

3) Initially it appears to be very free-player friendly and the client size is very small (around 300mb) so there is absolutely no harm for you in trying it.


Again, I don't see myself playing this card game, but I can see and appreciate the effort put into it. Just be wary about picking your initial deck. It can be a dealbreaker

if you don't know how to play it. For those of you that like it, please do have fun and I hope this game succeeds.

reviewText:
An excellent digital CCG so far.  It uses a mechanical template more similar to Magic than to Hearthstone, but even then it has made some major mechanical changes, and does not feel like a bad clone.  As a long term cardboard CCG player (primarily the extremely complex and deep Legend of the Five Rings), I'm glad to see a game that isn't emulating Hearthstone (which was too simplistic mechanically for me).

Mechanical Differences with Magic:

Dual Resource Management - The basic resource generator can either be played to increase your mana or to increase your strength in that school of magic, allowing access to stronger cards.  Knowing when to do which is an important thing to figure out.

Resource Cantrip - Basic resources replace themselves which really helps the pacing of the game.

Resource Tutoring - There is a built in mechanic to prevent resource screw - you can discard a card to search the top of your deck for a resource.

Speed Mechanics - An interesting tweak to add other facets to the attack and block matchup.  Units can't block units that are faster than them allowing for some interesting tactical matchups.

Support Line - Allows interesting non combat abilities to be relatively safe during run of the mill combat, and creates a more interesting flying mechanic than just being unblockable (which is its down rare mechanic).


There are lots of other little differences of course, but many are lexical changes (terms that have been renamed).  All in all, it's a fun game with lots of potential.  It's worth at least checking out.

Ever since Hearthstone came out of beta, I've been thinking - all right, this is great fun, but can I have something more strategic, please? A game that is less about playing the optimal hand every turn and more about making tactical decisions that matter?
Spellweaver might just be that game.
There have been many entries in the digital deckbuilding game scene over the past few years, but somehow most of them have managed to take a step in the wrong direction, be it an unreasonable business model, unbalanced gameplay, bad developer support or simply lackluster production values.
Spellweaver, however, is attempting to tick all the right boxes and is doing a good job so far. It will look immediately familiar to everyone who has played a dueling card game, but has enough unique twists to the classic formula to grab their attention. The rules are easy to comprehend, but there are many strategic layers to be found and a lot of room for experimentation. It's also still very fresh, so new players shouldn't have any trouble amassing a decent collection of cards. The business model is pretty generous in that regard. So if you want to get in on the ground floor, now is the time.
Apart from that, the game has some exciting deckbuilding possibilities. The are six different card factions and, unlike Hearthstone, Spellweaver supports multi-faction decks. The game is currently at the stage where it's really exciting to see where it goes with future card releases. If it manages to develop an interesting and reasonably dynamic meta, this game could really shine among other competitors.
The overall presentation is great as well - nothing spectacular, but nicely polished and professional-looking. If there's one complaint I have, it's that the animations can feel too slow and floaty"

reviewText:
Summary:

A nice mix of what is good about Hearthstone and Magic. The main draw for me personally is that it fixes what I dislike most about magic oustide of the massive money investment you need to play Magic. It accelerates acquizition of land cards or in this game, shrines. If you've ever hated not drawing lands Spellweaver has a system in which you can shuffle one card of your choice back into the deck and look at the top 5 cards of your deck, if any are shrines(lands) you can add that to your hand. That and the fact that the shrines are more mulilayered, some giving you new hero powers for example and the fact that you can choose whether you want to increase your mana(which is identical to HS in use but not in how you acquire it) or power level which is a flat resource that never depletes but is required to play certain cards.

So for me that's huge, I hated having to draw land cards in the f2p versions of Magic and potentially not being able to play anything. This keeps the game fun and fast without the need for cards that ramp up your lands like in Magic.


Outside of that, the game is very much like Magic except with the addition of the mechanic I listed and the hero power mechanics, which change the game very drastically. The card art and certain card designs, effects and archetypes are very familiar if you play Magic. But it's unique enough to not feel like a complete copy. There are more complex mechanics like the support line and the speed mechanic and the way in which you block is a bit different than Magic as well. So don't be fooled by it's appearance. There's a lot to enjoy here and a lot of fun unique mechanics to learn.

CONS:

Crafting/Disenchanting

My main issue with the game right now is the way in which you disenchant cards to craft new ones. You use shrines as currencies, which if you read what I said before are lands. The problem in this game is you need to specifically have shrines for the color in which you are crafting for. And not just that, you need to have at least 20 shrines at all times, so you can't disenchant below that. Why does this matter? Well, at the start you have 0 shrines, you get 20 from the starter decks. So what this means is, you need to either one disenchant a lot of cards of a certain color to first meet the 20 shrine limit before you can even start earning shrines that will go towards disenchanting OR you have to unlock the starter deck for each class which costs 40k gold, which is about 3 packs(it's quite a lot). You can get starter decks by leveling up but it will take a lot of hours to do this. So realistically you'll be spending either a lot of time or potentially money to get enough shrines to make cards you want. Which is nothing new, but the way in which you do it in Spellweaver is very unintuitive. Rather than have a flat rate, it's set up behind this 20 shrine minimum and not just that you have to then transfer shrines from different colors over to the color in which you want to create a card for, but not just that, it taxes you shrines, so the exchange rate isn't even a 1-1 ratio. Imagine in HS if you disenchanted a Hunter card but then had to transfer the dust to Mage first before being able to use it for a Mage card of your choice, but that 100 dust you got from disenchanting got reduced to 80. You'd be ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

Art, UI and Game Options

So if you've taken a second to look at the gameplay, you'll notice right off the bat that this game does not have the most unique appearance. It's card art looks very similar to Magic, it's main menu while efficient in what it does is bland. Even the name isn't interesting. It comes off too much like a Magic clone, and that will hurt it imo. It could really use a rehaul in a lot of areas to help give it it's own unique style that it really needs. The game options however are bare bones, the game is locked at 30 fps and while there is a windowed mode, you cannot adjust the resolution of it, so you'll be stuck with an awkward and ugly game window if you choose to go that route while playing. The 30 fps isn't too bad, you'll get used to it but if you go from other TCGs that run higher you might be annoyed by it.

Conclusion:

Overall though, it's a very good game. Fixes thing you might dislike from other TCGs and innovates with it's own twists. The areas in which it lacks while very important can be adjusted and overcome. The core gameplay is great and fills a solid niche between Magic and Hearthstone.

reviewText:
Spellweaver offers a really interesting set of cards to play around with and as it is a new title those new to the genre will not be overwhelmed by the card pool like in other such games. The artwork and overall flavour are also strong points.

The actual mechanics take some of the core concepts of other games and add a few unqiue elements; the speed aspect of differant cards adds an interesting additional component to game decisions for example. The devs seem very eager to test new ideas and make changes based on feedback so this is also a big plus.

In terms of price which is often a real issue with games like this, spellweaver offers a really gentle entry level for most players. I was able to unlock 4 starters and get a good number of booster packs just by playing and learning the basics for free. After this the starter pack is a good first purchase if you like the game; between that and the extra boosters you get by playing and earning gold, for about £15 you will have enough cards to make a decent deck and start playing other people. £15 is a pretty low cost for so much entertainment so it is hard to fault the payment model as it stands. How much you spend therefore is up to you. You can probably do well at the game with what this gets you if you get the mechanics down and practice but to top the leader boards I would imagine you would have to fully optimize your deck and as with any game like this that could get expensive; for the average player a few purchases here and there will keep the game fun enough I suspect.

Apart from the points mentioned it is worth noting also that as this is a new game, those joining have the unique chance to watch the game develop from its first set as they themselves get better at the game which itself is an exciting prospect.

Recommended!

reviewText:
The shrine concept is a strong compromise between the land mechanics from MTG that allows for factions/colors and the reduction in mana screw that comes from Hearthstones automatic mana crystals. Shrines double as both mana or color but you can only choose one option per shrine card you play, and you can only play one shrine card per turn.

The balance in the game is decent. The devs actively nerf or buff cards as necessary for meta diversity. The starter decks are okay. Good enough for AI matches. The factions are not equal as of March 26 2016, so your ease of playing and progress is dependent on picking the correct factions. (Although you can eventually unlock everything.) Getting the first three factions is not too difficult. You start with a deck and get a free one every 5 levels. Getting to level 15 is not too difficult so you should have 4 starter decks within a reasonable amount of time.

One complaint from new players is the AI quest difficulty, especially for Queen Aleyanna. Do note that a new player isn't expected to be able to immediately beat it. I re-started the game multiple times until I had a very strong opening hand before I beat it.

Mechanics such as multi-aspect decks, multi-blocking and the support row are not explained by the game (although maybe the tutorial's been updated since February). Use the forums as it's fairly active and you'll find tips and decklists there.

Product received for free

A product that improved Magic the Gathering.. wtf?

First things first, ive been playing games and computer games for 30 years now. Cause of this, i like in depth complex games that requires you to think. Games that will not handfed you anything and where you are free to use your creativity as much as you like.

For those that are familiar with Magic the Gathering, this will prolly be a pleasent suprise to you. Its much the same, however, as I first stated (and i guess many MtG veterans would kill me for saying it), this game is actually what MtG is missing, and then im thinking about the card game, not the money-pushing wannabe online versions on it.

Spellweaver has it all. Compex and intruiging gameplay packed into a sweet UI and a user friendly, well designed framework. Its free to play, and you can buy premium currency, however this game lets you get gold in descent amounts, so you dont need to do it.

Now, so what are the reasons this is an improvement to MtG.

FIrst of all, Spellweaver introduces mechanics to avoid sitting without mana. It costs, and its a gamble, but it even out the worst of the mana probems that can destroy a good MtG game. The first mechanic is that you can make one mulligan without loosing any cards, but you can only make one. reviewText:
I have a background in duelyst and Hearthstone (with a bit of very casual MTG). I don't claim to be an amazing player, but I'm not new to this genre either. Duelyst and hearthstone specifically really sucked me in and I have pretty good collections and lots of hours in both of those. I grant that I haven't delved nearly as much into this game or watched high level play like I have the other two. But after getting two of the starting decks (elves and dominion) my conclusion is that this game is just super frustrating to play.

For one, despite opening what felt like seven million cards the game threw at me, I didn't feel like my collection was growing. Since I only had two of of the factions' starting decks that meant that most of the cards I opened were completely useless. The cards that I had opened in-faction, moreover, weren't very exciting because I either already had them or I needed 2-3 more of them to get them to show up with any consistency.

Secondly, combat seems interesting at first, but gets a lot less fun as time goes on. Minions heal after attacking, like in MTG, but can target other minions specifically, like in heathstone. While speed theoretically restricts which minions can attack which, and you can move minions to the support line to protect them, most minions seem to fall into pretty predictable averages and spawn on the front line. Combine this with a severe lack of board clear and, as a new player, the game can quickly become about getting the big board before your opponent and eternally outvaluing him with slightly bigger or better minions until he dies, which is boring when you're winning and feels terrible when you losing.

In the end I ended up being more frustrated every time I played the game, even against AI opponents, who were either too easy (presumably because their draws were bad) or too hard (because their draws were better than mine). I never felt like I was making a really smart (or even a really dumb) decision like in Hearthstone or Duelyst. I ended up yelling at the game because it was so annoying. And that's something considering that in Hearthstone isn't free of frustration either.

I'm not saying that this game has no redeeming qualities. The quest system for earning currency is alright. The rate of card acquisition is certainly better than hearthstone. The visual, music, and sound work do the job of making everything pretty (although the constant clanging whenever you enter combat grates on my nerves a bit). But gameplay, man. I had problems with it.

I liked the game, at least until I started playing Trials almost exclusively. Draft mode is the mode I have most fun playing in TCGs. At first I thought packs would be the entry to drafts in Spellweaver so I hoarded those playing with just the basic decks. Trials does have some issues though. It is more evident when playing Trials that previous experience with games such as MTG can be a bad thing. You do not have the option to respond to what your opponent does in the main phase before the combat. that can be frustrating, but it is not the reason for the thumbs down.
The real issue is that some of the factions seem to have an advantage in this game mode. If you can get purple as one of the two factions you have a much greater chance of winning. Purple is beatable, but certainly have the advantage with fast cards and heroes with riddiculous powers. The raven hero in particular is just riddiculously bonkers compared to other heroes. Most people seem to have noticed this too, since I keep seing that one over and over, unfortunately on the wrong side of the gameboard... In constructed formats (Ranked/Friendly/PvE) it seems less of an issue.
The game does have potential, and the draft mode is fun. But if you have the option to pick between two different heroes with the same faction combination, and a third with just one new faction it is not much of a choice.
Now what would make the game mode better? Maybe introducing neutral cards that require no faction level or where the faction level is just unspecified. Maybe the set of cards are balanced for one game mode and not the other? Some cards could be restricted/banned? Maybe a choice of three different faction combos would make things less forced?
Anyway, thumbs down for balance issues in the Trials/Draft gamemode.

Unlike Magic the Gathering, every land/mana point you gain lets you draw 1 card. This replenishes the card that you disposed of to build your mana pool.

3. Hero Abilities
I found this quite unique and refreshing. Every hero you choose has an ability that unlocks upon fulfilling certain prerequisites. You even gain new abilities from your land/shrine cards. Kind of similar to using the heroes in MTG.

4. Easy GUI
Super simple and intuitive. Just click and drag your card to your target to attack it.

CONS
1. Pay To Win
No CCG can escape from this model. If you need a rare card to complete that combo, you just to suck it up. Pay and buy that booster. Sure you can do quests to grind gold, but cold hard currency will always triumph.

2. Themes
So generic. Undead vampire nobles, elves of the forest, barbarian wastelands, the theme is a copy of any other Tolkienesque/Warcraft themed game. You basically see elves, gnomes, dwarves, angels, vampires, etc. The same creatures in Might and Magic Duel of Champions.
